bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, May 10, 1925

div1.p: [Carter] reports that MacFie is being sent to Africa to research the breeding of Stegomyia in mud puddles. He discusses his health.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, May 10, 1925
div1.opener:
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 10, 1925.
Dear Scannell:
div1.p:
I am very glad to get your letter of May 4th., and to know you
are in the U. S.

The Marine Hospital in Chelsea was my first station (May 1879)
when I entered the U. S. Service.

Stevens, the Dean of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine,
in whose publication my article, to which you refer, appeared, wrote
me, on receipt of it last fall, that the matter had been brought up
before their Board and that they were sending MacFie (I think the
best man they now have in Stegomyia biology) to West Africa to re-
investigate the breeding of this mosquito about Salt Pond: Secondee
etc.

I have no doubt that good field men could meet thy problem of com-
pulsory breeding of Stegomyia, yet it seemed well to indicate at
once how this could be readily and inexpensively done. If, however,
in this region Stegomyia breeds in ponds: puddles: dtiches etc. with-
out compulsion (and that this be general) I feel sure that while the
problem would be soluble that the cost would be prohibitive to do so--
being, I should say, from 100 to.1,000 times as great as if it only
used collections of water in artificial containers or similar things,
things,
-2-
and if I were sure it did so, I would not advise the I. H. B. to attempt
work in this region.

I believe with you that with the men that the I. H. B. has in Brazil
and elsewhere that it should be able to clean up West Africa, but I pro-
foundly doubt if the word “soon” could be put in this sentence before “be
able” as you place it.

I am not as well as you could wish, being confined to my bed practi-
cally since the 2nd. of January and absolutely for a little over three
weeks. I am still trying to work a little, however, and if you can come
to Washington both Laura and I will be glad to see Mrs. Scannell: “Sonny”
and yourself or any one of you.
With very best wishes to you all from us both,
